Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Not sure where this should go exactly, but the faq for setting up staking seems to make no sense at all for those with the GUI wallet (the commands listed return as errors).   How does one manage their coins for staking using only the CLI commands available in the 0.3.9 CLI command set?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <karero> @jimboscott you mean staking but not mining? I believe you are always staking when mining. In the GUI if you set the number of threads to 0, you are staking. Have you tried that with the CLI?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <karero> If you are already mining with one process you can try this 
./verus setgenerate true 0

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <karero> Or when starting  try 
./verusd -gen -genproclimit=0

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> I know that's what it says, other sources state the coins must go to a Z address first, then come back to a public address before they will stake.   That is what I am wanting solid guidance on.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <karero> That‘s true for mined or minted coins

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <karero> Here's what I wrote in #faq-draft about time locked coins & staking:
The Zcash protocol requires you to send all coins received by mining or staking (reward transactions) once unlocked to a private address and then to a public/transparent address before you can use them either for staking or for making transactions (that’s how you make use of your rewarded coins = coinbase coins). So, once your coins loose their time lock, in the GUI first generate a private address and then go to the „Send“ screen and use „Shield a coinbase transaction“ (will take some time, likely 5 min, but may be up to 20 min, much longer than from a public/transparent address to another). Finally you transfer the coins from your private address back to (one of) your public / transparent address(es) and you’ll automatically start staking.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: 0.045/500 * 1440 that is how many blocks a day roughly (network hash at 500)

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: But the luck plays a part

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <karero> @bigmopap you could calculate it like this (but remember this is just a statistical probability): you have 45MH/s. The network is at 380 GH (varies). There are roughly 1440 block rewards, in theory 50% for mining and 50% for staking. Thus 720 minable block rewards per day. With your power 45/380000*720 = 0.085 blocks per day. Or 11.7 days for one block. I guess network hash will increase soon.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <superbergs> @jimboscott thanks mate i appreciate the help!

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content:
just in case, I noticed that it seems that dynamically changing the genproclimit via setgenerate true XX end up in going very slow if the point is to go up : an example : I start with genproclimit=1, 20MH, then go to genproclimit=20 : move very slow to 40 MH.
When I just stop it and restart directly with a genproclimit=20 : I go directly to 240 MH

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: and it keeps stabilized at that hashps

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> <dwy> that is because it does a simple average with how long the current node has been up. If you sync without mining (which is recommended), then turn mining on, the hashrate slowly climbs to what you expect. But if you stop and restart, you will stabilize on the correct hashrate very quickly.

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: thanks, learned another thing today 😃

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @n3rfed Run every thread you can - that would be 8.  My son mines this on a Ryzen 5 and he is getting around 170 I think.   I am hashing about 1.3 Gh/s here and I get 2-4 blocks per day.  One Ryzen 5 is probably going to find a block every 4 days or so, but luck might be such that you get two in a day... or none in two weeks.
